abstract: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business.
snippet: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business, one the Internet company swiftly rejected on Saturday.

headline.main: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive
headline.print_headline: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business, one the Internet company swiftly rejected on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business, one the Internet company swiftly rejected on Saturday.

headline.main: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive

abstract: Microsoft, Yahoo and Carl C. Icahn can’t even agree on the basic facts about what happened last weekend. No wonder they can’t engineer some kind of deal.
snippet: Microsoft, Yahoo and Carl C. Icahn can’t even agree on the basic facts about what happened last weekend. No wonder they can’t engineer some kind of deal.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft, Yahoo and the corporate raider — er, stockholder activist — Carl C. Icahn traded insults Monday as they passed around blame for this weekend’s failed attempt to restart some serious dealmaking between the two Internet companies.

headline.main: Which Way Is Up? Yahoo, Microsoft and Icahn Can’t Agree
